column4: This is the first time I come to this channel and I can see that it is completely Useless. I'm and advanced Linux user and I can solve most of my problems myself but this is just another RTFM channel...              RTFM is not Ubuntu!!!!!
Ubuntu is the most useful linux around, with the support of MINT but this channel is a disgrace
And Arch is a better distro, that is if you really are a more 'advanced' user.

I've done all that shit. I've used slack, gentoo and the rest of them. Now I want to relax. That means... I wan't a new device to work when I bring it. Or a device to work without 10 minutes of work to get it to work... I bet you know what I mean
Then you've never used Arch.
that's because more people are here for help than to help
To be honest, I have not. I figured it would be kind of the same as early slackware
Not even close
Better package management than ubuntu imho
But ofcourse when it comes to the Kernel. It's not the same
It's easy
Always up to date with rolling release... and an up-to-date system is as simply as pacman -Syu
Package management is not my problem. It's the functionality. Which is really good in ubunty but!... The stability is getting me down
functionality is a choice of the user.
I am a long time user of FreeBSD is that helps at all
Then you'd love Arch
Give it a shot.
Arch is what you make it, not made out of the box

To be honest. I've tried so many linux distros and unices that I've seen that id doesn't really matter what you do it's all fundamentally the same unless there are some major phlilosophycal or legal differeces between the two os'es
Just try Arch and thank me later. Plus, stay on topic so I don't get kicked out of here

Sorry. I'm very drunk and stoned. However... I think I'm making a valid point. I've used linux for a long time. I like all the scripts and code that Ubuntu makes to make things automated and that's why I don't thing why arch will get me going. I used to love the reading and figuring out but now I just want to relax :D
That's why I'm so annoyed by the constant kernel panics
